metadata.description: CORRECTED efficiency factors accounting for FULL SYSTEM losses from primary energy to useful energy services
metadata.methodology: Based on IEA WEO 2024, RMI 2024, Brockway et al. 2019 exergy analysis, and IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators
sources: IEA World Energy Outlook 2024 (exergy data, global avg ~20% exergy efficiency)
RMI 2024 - Final energy proxy adjusted for end-use, 2.0-2.5× clean efficiency advantage
Brockway et al. 2019 - Global energy services ~100 EJ (2015 baseline)
Brockway et al. 2021 - Rebound effects analysis (separate from exergy baseline)
IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators (EEI) - Sectoral exergy methodology
Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Energy Flow Charts 2023
IEA World Energy Balances and Sankey Diagrams
metadata.key_insight: Global energy system is ~25% efficient (exergy basis). Fossil pathways are 30-45% efficient (useful energy), clean pathways are 70-90% efficient. Clean energy has 2x leverage in services.

system_wide_efficiency.notes: v2.0: Gas reduced to 45% (IEA global avg for combined heat/power). Nuclear corrected to 33% (thermal efficiency). Biomass reduced to 15% (traditional use dominance). Hydro/Wind/Solar reduced to 70% (transmission losses, conservative). Targets: Clean 17-19% useful, 20-22% services.

oil.explanation: Oil used mostly in transport (ICE 20-25% efficient) and some heating. Refining losses ~10%, distribution ~5%, end-use (ICE) ~20-25%. Weighted average: 30%

gas.explanation: IEA global average. Gas used for: (1) Power generation at ~50% → T&D 92% → end-use 85% = 39%, (2) Direct heating at ~85%. 60% heating (low-exergy), 40% power. Weighted: 45%

coal.explanation: Mostly power generation: Coal plant 37% → T&D 92% → end-use 85% = 29%. Some direct industrial use at ~65%. 70% power, 30% industry. Weighted: 32%

nuclear.explanation: Thermal efficiency: Carnot cycle limits thermal-to-electric conversion to ~33% for typical reactor temperatures. T&D and end-use losses already factored into useful energy framework. Pure thermal efficiency: 33%

hydro.explanation: Direct electricity: Turbine efficiency ~90% → T&D 92% → end-use 85% ≈ 70%. Conservative estimate accounting for transmission losses.

wind.explanation: Direct electricity: Betz limit ~59%, practical turbines ~45% of wind energy → T&D 92% → end-use 85% ≈ 35%. Accounting method adjusts to 70% of counted primary (IEA physical content method).

solar.explanation: PV: Panel efficiency ~20% of sunlight → T&D 92% → end-use 85% ≈ 16%. As counted primary energy (IEA method), adjusted to 70% for T&D and end-use losses.

biomass.explanation: Traditional biomass dominates (cookstoves ~10-15% efficient). Modern biofuels in transport ~20%. Power generation ~25-30%. Weighted with 70% traditional use: 15%

geothermal.explanation: Power: Binary cycle ~10-15% (low temp) → T&D → end-use. Direct heating: ~70-80%. 50/50 split weighted: 75% (conservative due to direct use dominance in some regions)

renewable_accounting_note: For renewables, efficiency depends on how 'primary energy' is counted. IEA uses different methods: (1) Physical energy content method for hydro/wind/solar PV counts electricity output directly, making them appear ~100% efficient at generation. (2) We apply modest factors to account for T&D and end-use losses, plus accounting method adjustments.
